Description: Terracotta statuette of woman. Head fragment only. She wears her hair parted in the middle under a veil. Pushed into a single one-piece mould with a plain back, solid. Simple work with prominent features, such as nose and eyes. Orange-brown clay with common mica.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Parallels in this style of seated and standing women (deities?) and in this fabric were found at Halikarnassos and have been dated to the early 4th century BC (Higgins1970, 459, 460).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.003) (Phase 3)
